NYU > MEIS > Faculty > Francis E. Peters                                                             Back to  previous page                                              Francis E. Peters   Professor Emeritus of Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies and Religious Studies Ph.D. 1961, Princeton.   Office Address: Department of Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies  50 Washington Square South  New York, NY 10012 Email:             Areas of Research/Interest   Islamic history and religion; comparative Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.     Publications   The First Frontier: The Christian and Muslim War in Spain (in progress) The Voice, The Word The Books. The Sacred Scriptures of the Jews, Christians and Muslims (Princeton University Press, 2008) The Children op Abraham. A New Edition (Princeton University Press, 2006) The Monotheists. Jews Christians and Muslims in Conflict and Competition (Princeton University Press, 2005) Islam: A Guide for Jews and Christians (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2003) The Monotheists: Jews, Christians, and Muslims in Conflict and Competition, 2 vols. (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2003) Muhammad and the Origins of Islam (Albany: SUNY Press, 1994) The Hajj: The Muslim Pilgrimage to Mecca and the Holy Places (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1994) Mecca and the Hijaz: A Literary History of the Muslim Holy Land (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1994) Judaism, Christianity, and Islam: The Classical Texts and Their Interpretations , 3 vols. (Princeton: Princeton University Press) Jerusalem and Mecca: The Typology of the Holy City in the Near East (New York: New York University Press, 1987) Jerusalem: Holy City in the Eyes of Chroniclers, Visitors, Pilgrims, and Prophets from the Days of Abraham to the Beginnings of Modern Times (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1985)     Update your faculty profile                           Updated on 08/26/2014       Contact Us | © New York University , Arts and Science

Muhammad and the Origins of Islam     Muhammad and the Origins of Islam   F. E. Peters     From the Preface  Muhammad stands at the Islamic center, of course, as he has from the  beginning; and those who have sought to stand beside him, or even  perhaps within him, have essayed biographies of the Prophet of  Islam....The present work is biographical, but it is at the same time  something broader. It is an inquiry --or perhaps a joint inquiry since  the reader will be provided with the same sources available to the  historian-- into the religious environment of the person Muslims hail as  the "Envoy of God" and an attempt to trace his progress along the path  from paganism to that distintive form of monotheism called Islam .  The Arabic word islam means "submission," and though we may never  come to any firm conviction as to why this man first "submitted" to the  Almighty God in Western Arabia in the seventh Christian century, then  persistently and persuasively convinced others to do likewise, we do  have at hand a large body of evidence to enable us to try, as well as a  long tradition of scholarship from Muslims and non-Muslims who have  gone before along this way.
